Health care facilities and providers (public and private) should continue with their masking policies until 80% of eligible PEI residents are fully vaccinated.    For all Health PEI Facilities, including Long-Term Care, patients or residents may have visitors and Partners in Care (either indoors or outdoors). All patients or residents may designate up to three (3) Partners in Care who will be allowed to visit at any time of day to support them. Partners in Care are not required to schedule their visit as they are considered part of the care team for the patient or resident. Partners in Care are encouraged to inform the facility of when they plan to visit.     Long-Term Care residents may designate up to six (6) visitors in addition to their three (3) Partners in Care. Designated visitors must schedule their visit. Visitors must wear a medical grade mask for indoor visits in Long-term Care facilities. Physical distancing is required between residents and designated visitors. Designated visitors are not permitted to have physical contact with residents or visit in a resident’s room (unless at end of life).      Health PEI facilities, patients may have visitors and Partners in Care (either indoors or outdoors) at any time; however a maximum of three (3) visitors, including the Partner(s) in Care, may be present at the bedside at one time. Length and frequency of bedside visits are dependent on the site’s operational plan. Visitors and patients must remain six (6) feet apart at all times.       https://archive.vn/IjT3W

On July 13, the province announced that some protections in long term care facilities will be removed, in two phases. Phase 1 is to begin as soon as feasible for each facility. In phase 1, visitor restrictions are removed, however they must still go through screening before entering; dining and recreation limits are also removed for residents; and residents no longer have to be screened or quarantined if returning from off-site, as long as they are not returning from an outbreak site and are fully vaccinated. All other restrictions are still in place, like staff and volunteers being screened every day, staff only able to work at one facility, enhanced cleaning, outbreak measures and testing guidelines. All facilities are expected to be in phase 1 by July 31.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210719000548/https://www.alberta.ca/release.cfm?xID=795464C13C264-E6FD-0B71-C8494365B3D0BB53
